item.title: Ticket #708 (IXR lib cannot call server methods contained in a class object) updated
item.dc:creator: ringmaster
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #708 (IXR lib cannot call server methods contained in a class object) updated
item.dc:creator: ringmaster
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #708 (IXR lib cannot call server methods contained in a class object) created
item.dc:creator: ringmaster
item.description:
Using the new 'xmlrpc_methods' plugin hook, I tried to create a new XML-RPC method via a plugin. My plugin code is contained in a class to avoid namespace issues (See: ​http://codex.wordpress.org/Plugin_API#Avoiding_Function_Name_Collisions ).

I added the method to the method list using the class object array method ( $callback=array(&$myobject, 'methodname') ), but IXR_Server cannot execute methods declared in this manner. As a result, the only way to implement XML-RPC server methods inside a class is to extend the IXR_Server class, which can't be done from the xmlrpc_methods hook in WordPress.

item.title: Ticket #587 (Comments RSS shows latest entry url as itemlink for all items) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Status changed

item.title: Ticket #587 (Comments RSS shows latest entry url as itemlink for all items) updated
item.dc:creator: ColdForged
item.description:
Problem is that the comment_link_rss() function used by the wp-commentsrss2.php feed file is really only meant to return a link to the comments section of the post. Even so, for main site comment feeds this function uses get_permalink outside of a posts loop, so it always returns a link to the latest entry.

My solution involves adding a new function in wp-includes/comment-functions.php to return the URL of a specific comment. Here is that function:

function get_specific_comment_link() {

global $comment; return get_permalink( $comment->comment_post_ID ) . "#comment-" . $comment->comment_ID;

}

Then, in feed-functions.php, the comment_link_rss() function becomes:

function comment_link_rss() {

echo get_specific_comment_link();

}

Fixed feed example: ​http://www.coldforged.org/comments/feed/rss2/

item.title: Ticket #706 (get_the_title() ignores $id when testing for a protected post) updated
item.dc:creator: morganiq
item.description: Oops, I diffed the wrong version, one with only a partial fix. Please use the second attachment, protected-title-2.diff.

item.title: Ticket #705 (no moderation notification being sent) updated
item.dc:creator: bronski
item.description: changing != to !== seems to do the trick, diff supplied.

item.title: Ticket #706 (get_the_title() ignores $id when testing for a protected post) updated
item.dc:creator: morganiq
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #706 (get_the_title() ignores $id when testing for a protected post) updated
item.dc:creator: morganiq
item.description:
1. Create a password protected post
  2. Insert a call to 'echo get_the_title(SOME_ID)' somewhere within the loop, where SOME_ID is the ID of a post known to exist
  3. When a password-protected post is encountered in the loop, "Protected: " is added to the beginning of the post title for SOME_ID, even though that post is not protected.

item.title: Ticket #706 (get_the_title() ignores $id when testing for a protected post) created
item.dc:creator: morganiq
item.description: get_the_title() has an optional argument of $id, allowing one to get the title of a post other than the one currently in the loop. However, when it checks to see if the post is password protected (to add "Protected: " to the front), it ignores $id and checks the title of the current loop post.

item.title: Ticket #705 (no moderation notification being sent) updated
item.dc:creator: bronski
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #705 (no moderation notification being sent) created
item.dc:creator: bronski
item.description: on 10 Jan 2005 20:21:06 in version 1.26 of functions-post.php an if-line " if ( 'spam' != $approved ) { If it's spam save it silently for later crunching" has been introduced. Since that moment no moderation notifications are being sent. Deletion of that line and its closing curly bracket let those mails come. So there seems to be something wrong about the test-condition ( 'spam' != $approved ).

item.title: Ticket #704 (protected pages don't ask for password) updated
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #704 (protected pages don't ask for password) created
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description:
I created a page as a subpage of another page. I set a password on this subpage. When visiting the site with another browser where I wasn't logged in to WordPress, the page fully showed up in the browser - no password was asked. The page was told to be protected in the management, but the password just wasn't asked.

The speciality of this page might be that it was empty - I have some scripts that create page templates and I set up empty pages that just select this template to show it's stuff.

item.title: Ticket #702 (add category_save_pre filter) updated
item.dc:creator: kellan
item.description:
Actually, you should probably ignore that first suggestion. spending a little more time with the 1.5 codebase, I found the 'preprocess_comment' filter. It would be more generally useful not to mention add to the consistency to use add a similar preprocess_post filter.

I've attached a patch to do this.

item.title: Ticket #407 (import-mt.php does not recognise breaks between entries) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
I didn't export it from MT, I put text data from another journalling tool into MT export format. Rather than go through the entire dump altering the order, I guess I will just import it all into 1.2 and then upgrade.

Is there any particular reason why WP specifies the order and the MT specs don't? Also, any reason why this was added to 1.5 when it isn't in 1.2?

item.title: Ticket #703 (comment approval status ought to be reloaded after comment_post hook) updated
item.dc:creator: fwenzel
item.description: Okay, recent completion of source code with new hooks makes it possible to change everything flawlessly when the correct hooks are used. So close this, please, and sorry for the inconvenience.

item.title: Ticket #703 (comment approval status ought to be reloaded after comment_post hook) updated
item.dc:creator: fwenzel
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #703 (comment approval status ought to be reloaded after comment_post hook) created
item.dc:creator: fwenzel
item.description:
In functions-post.php, there's the comment_post hook:

do_action('comment_post', $comment_id);

afterwards, moderator notification is done if applicable. But what if a plugin, attached to the comment_post hook, changed the "approved" status of the comment to "unapproved"? Then the "new comment" notification is sent although the comment is in fact *held for moderation*.

So I suggest that the $approved variable is reloaded out of the database after the plugin hook for more flexibily in writing plugins.
